Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The project is still in exploratory discussions, and alternative approaches can be proposed later
Story: I glanced at the overflowing laundry basket, the colors and whites tangled together, a silent reminder of the chores waiting for me. My husband had mentioned this morning that the kids needed clean uniforms for their activities tomorrow. I knew he expected me to help out, to share the load, especially since he’d been working late all week. But as I reached for the detergent, my phone buzzed with a message from my project manager: “Can you join a quick call to brainstorm some new approaches?” The project was still in its early stages, nothing urgent yet, but I also knew how much my input was valued in these initial discussions. I felt the familiar tug-of-war inside me—wanting to be a reliable partner at home, but also not wanting to miss the chance to shape the direction of our work. My mind raced, weighing the expectations on both sides, feeling the pressure build as I stood between the laundry room and my laptop, uncertain which role to step into first.
